item.title: Complete Guide to Amazon SQS and Amazon SNS With MassTransit
item.description: In this article, we'll explore how to use Amazon SQS and SNS for asynchronous messaging in .NET applications. We'll also see how MassTransit simplifies the process, enabling you to build robust message-driven systems.

item.title: The Tyranny of Defaults: Why the Worst Monopolies Are in Your Mind
item.description: Ever wondered why you type “Google” without thinking? It's not just a habit—it's a mental monopoly. See how defaults hijack your brain and explore simple steps to reclaim your mental freedom.

item.title: PyTorch is dead. Long live JAX.
item.description: Assumed audience: ML researchers who frequently work with PyTorch, but are interested in trying out JAX or have yet to be convinced.

item.title: Bun DIY: Tailwind Lite | christophilus
item.description: When I started my zero-dependency Bun application experiment, I had no plans to build a CSS processing layer. My plan was to just hand-roll my CSS like any self-respecting neanderthal. But... I'd forgotten how much I like the convenience of fire and wheels and tools and suchlike. Within a few minutes, I was already well on my way to writing a steaming pile of unmaintainable spaghetti. Thus, I decided to write Tailwind from scratch with zero dependencies.

item.title: Can GPT generate random numbers ?
item.description:
Well a random thought came to my mind if GPT can really generate a random number ?
Best thing is to find out yourself.
First thing is to quickly write boiler plates around random number generation using the cohere sonet model.
async def generate_random_number(till: int): temperature = random.random(

item.title: Are you considering Event Sourcing? Think again.
item.description: Are you considering doing event sourcing? Maybe you have read that it is necessary for your project or that you will have great benefits in doing so. If so, I ask you to think about an alternative. Maybe you already have something of equal capacity in the tooling that you use and could extract all the benefits for a fraction of the cost. What is that something? Your old SQL RDBMS (MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, Oracle, etc).

item.title: That's the Sound of Devs Working on the Chain Gang
item.description: Are you a manager desperate to cover up their own lack of productivity and general uselessness by implementing a system that will allow you to constantly lament your underlings apparent lack of productivity?
